intro: Munnozia luyensis, commonly known as the Luyens' mallow, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton, and is characterized by its showy, five-petaled flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in arid or semi-arid environments. Its leaves are usually narrow and gray-green, while its flowers range in color from white to pink. Munnozia luyensis is often found in desert scrub and chaparral habitats, where it plays a role in local pollination and ecological balance.
